items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This mornings high tide has now passed, and the situation on this stretch of the coast is improving. Spring tides peak on Friday, and so astronomical tide levels will remain high through this period. It is  therefore possible that further alerts may be required in the coming days, should the forecast change

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.70mAOD at 15:30 on 06/10/21 and 4.75mAOD at 03:45 on 07/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 85 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:15 AM on 07/10/2021.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
Highest tide level is at 12:15 AM on 07/10/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings.
We will continue to monitor the forecast. 
Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
    
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall

Spring tides peak on Friday, and so astronomical tide levels will remain high through this period. It is  therefore possible that further alerts and warnings may be required in the coming days, should the forecast change

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11pm this evening and 3am tomorrow morning Thursday 7th October.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.74 mAODN at 00:45am, on Thursday 7th October, which is 0.02m below tide tables, wind Force 1, Westerly.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 7th October.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. This Flood Alert is likely to remain in place for several days. A Flood Warning is also in place for Keswick Campsite. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 07/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwentwater is high following several days of rain. Areas most at risk of flooding include low lying land bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this warning if necessary. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast.
We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high on the middle River Mole and flooding of roads and farmland near watercourses is still possible for the next 24 hours. The river level on the Mole at Leatherhead and Cobham is expected to peak later today. 

We expect river levels to remain high for the next 24 hours but no further significant rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and clearing trash screens.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 8pm on the 6th October.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message: The risk of flooding from the Rivers Colne and Radlett Brook has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further significant rainfall is currently forecast for over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation.

The River Adur is high, but is now slowly falling, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Minor flood impacts will ease, but some water will remain in fields, rural roads and gardens including properties near Mock Bridge near Shermanbury and the A281 at Mock Bridge. Very little rain is forecast for the remainder of the week. The river should continue to fall throughout Wednesday, returning to near normal Thursday afternoon (07/10/2021). Please continue to take care if driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, residual water could remain for a number of days. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding returns.

items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water may still be present. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No further significant rain is forecast over the next five days. 

We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Water levels are high on Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to several days of heavy rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

Over the last few days we have seen several bands of heavy rainfall in the River Roding catchment. This has meant that levels in the Roding have risen.

Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river is expected to continue throughout the day on Wednesday 6 October. The main areas of concern are Abridge, Loughton and Buckhurst Hill. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect the river to remain high today before slowly falling over the coming days.  No further rain is forecast over the next few days.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages.

This message will be updated by 7pm on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday, 05/10/21.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.   
No further rainfall is forecast overnight. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/10/21, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast.
We will continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, but we continue to monitor the situation in case the forecast changes. Please avoid contact with flood water, which may still be present.

The Western Rother is high through Fittleworth, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. The river level at Fittleworth could keep rising until Wednesday afternoon, but we estimate by no more than 5 centimetres. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and properties near Fittleworth Mill, Fittleworth. River levels at Lodsbridge near Selham are also high, and causing minor flood impacts, however river levels at Lodsbridge are now slowly falling. River levels between Liss and Midhurst have already fallen to normal. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. River levels at Lodsbridge should be significantly lower by Thursday 07/10/2021. It will take longer for river levels in Fittleworth to fall, perhaps until the weekend. Please keep flood protection measures in place in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth until river levels have fallen significantly further. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message: The risk of flooding from the Cripsey Brook has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
The water level in the Eastern Yar is now slowly reducing. Over the next 5 days, the weather will remain settled and fairly dry. No further impacts from the river are currently expected.

River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for scattered showers and drier weather going into the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Rivers Derwent, Team, Don and estuarine tributaries

floodArea.county: County Durham, Gateshead, Northumberland, South Tyneside, Sunderland
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, River Team, River Don

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Rivers Derwent, Team, Don and estuarine tributaries has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to roads and farmland is expected however they may be standing water seen for several days.

The River Ouse near Barcombe is still high but is now falling slowly, following Tuesday morning's heavy rain. Minor flood impacts will ease, but some water will remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads, including Barcombe Mills road, Fletching Mill Bridge and at Sharpsbridge. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week. The river will continue to fall, possibly returning to near normal at Barcombe by Wednesday evening (06/10/2021). River levels near Ardingly, Lindfield and on Sloop Lane have already returned to near normal. Please continue to take care if driving on routes vulnerable to flooding as residual water could remain for a couple of days. We continue to operate our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding returns.

items.description: Somerset coast at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
    
We continue to monitor the situation.

The River Arun has now peaked, following Tuesday's heavy rain. However, river levels will remain high between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham Quay throughout Wednesday, and flood water will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads in these areas. Minor flooding could affect the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week, but river levels are unlikely to have fallen significantly near Pallingham Quay until the weekend. River levels through Horsham and Broadbridge Heath are already almost at, or much closer to normal. Please keep flood protection products installed, if you have them, until river levels have fallen significantly further. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 20:00 Wednesday 06/10/2021.

The River Arun at Pulborough is still high and rising, following a very wet start to October. From 21:30 today (Wednesday 06/10/2021) flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields, and could affect gardens and approach properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and at Bridge Cottages, Greatham. At 02:30 on Thursday (07/10/2021), the river at Houghton Bridge in Amberley will peak at a similar height to that seen today at lunchtime, with water close to the tops of the banks. Flooding is not currently expected this week in Arundel or Ford. Very little rain is forecast for the rest of the week, which should allow the river to peak after high tide on Thursday afternoon (07/10/2021). The river is unlikely to return to a lower level until next week. Flood protection products are recommended to remain installed, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 10:00 on 07/10/2021.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta

items.message:
Over the last few days we have seen several bands of heavy rainfall in the Roding catchment. This has meant that levels in the river have risen.

Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river may continue today on Wednesday 6 October. The main areas of concern are Molehill Green, Dunmow, Ongar, Fyfield, High Ongar and Stapleford. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 

River levels have peaked and are starting to drop, however we expect the river to remain high today.  No further rain is forecast over the next few days.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages.

This message will be updated by 7pm on Wednesday or earlier if the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
This mornings high tide has now passed, and the situation on this stretch of the coast is improving. Spring tides peak on Friday, and so astronomical tide levels will remain high through this period. It is  therefore possible that further alerts may be required in the coming days, should the forecast change. Further upstream on the River Esk, flood alerts and warnings remain in force following heavy overnight rainfall.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue this evening Wednesday 06/10/2021. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly those around Maunby. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. River levels are now falling and we expect them to continue falling overnight. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.
